bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, July 3, 1918

div1.p: [Carter] wants to engage in yellow fever research once he is finished with his malaria work.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to Wickliffe Rose, July 3, 1918
div1.opener:
Extra Cantonment Sanitation, Field Office
Newport News, Va. July 3rd, 1918.
Box #613.
Dr. Mickliffe Rose,
International Health Commission,
61 - Broadway, N. Y.
Dear Dr. Rose:
div1.p:
Dr. Gorgos asked me May 24th, if I could go with
Noguchioand Kendall to Guayaquil for the investigation of yellow
fever. I thought it wrong to leave my present work and so ad-
vised him.

Yesterday the proposition came up to take leave of
absence and go under the auspices of the Commission to Guatamala
to suppress the epidemic there. This was different. It might be
that I would be worth more in the war doing this than in what I
am doing. Ultimately I mean for the present I am unquestionably
worth more where I am. There is no one available who can just
now fill my place in the Malaria Control about my cantonment.
I left the matter with the Bureau telling them that I thought I
ought not to go. I thing they will agree with me.

Personally I wanted both details. Either one the first
especially, had been very agreeable to me. It may be I am wrong
in my comparative evalivation of my present work and the Guata-
malan detail, yet I think as I have said and could decide no other
wise.

The yellow fever work is the very breath of my nostrils and
I had rather be engaged in it than in anything else. I think I
will have the Malaria work in such shape that I can leave it by
September 1st, certainly by September 15th, and if I can be of
use in any other yellow fever work after that time, I should be
available. I am getting old However.
